(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1991 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed.
and that the October 1992 Term is now convened. Today's orders of the
Court have been certified and filed with the Clerk. They will not be oth-
erwise announced."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1546. Bob Slagle, Chairman, Texas Democratic Party, Appel-
lant v. Louis Terrazas, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas. The judgment is affirmed. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 91-1862. David Gantt, etc., et al., Appellants v. Dean Skelos,
etc. et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of New York. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
New York with instructions to dismiss the appeal as moot. United
States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U. S. 36 (1950).
No. 91-2038. James Arthur "Art" Pope, et al., Appellants v. Daniel
T. Blue, Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of North Carolina. The judgment is affirmed. Justice
Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1493. Georgia, Petitioner v. Willie James Carr. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further consideration in
light of Georgia v. McCollum, 505 U. S. (1992).
No. 91-1593. Francisco Javier Munoz-Romo, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of the position asserted by the Solicitor General in his
brief for the United States filed June 24, 1992.
No. 91-1793. James Albert Coones, Petitioner v. Federal Deposit In-
surance Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Taylor v. Freeland & Kronz, 503 U. S.
(1992).
No. 91-1925. City of Rocklin, et al., Petitioners v. Sierra Lakes Re-
serve. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Yee v. City of Escondido, California, 503 U. S.
(1992).
No. 91-1938. Yellow Freight System, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit with directions
to dismiss as moot. United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U. S. 36
(1950).
No. 91-1988. Frank Longo, Petitioner v. United States Postal Serv-
ice, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Burson v. Freeman, 504 U. S. (1992).
No. 91-7430. Lawrence Jackson, Petitioner v. Illinois. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further consideration in
light of Morgan v. Illinois, 504 U. S. (1992).
No. 91-8445. Miguel Angel Bacigalupo, Petitioner v. California. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
3
tition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further
consideration in light of Stringer v. Black, 503 U. S. - (1992).
No. 91-8584. Anthony John Ponticelli, Petitioner v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Espinosa v. Florida, 505 U. S. — (1992).
No. 92-249. American Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Myron Wolens, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further
consideration in light of Morales v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., 504
U. S. — (1992).
No. 92-5228. George M. Hodges, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Espinosa v. Florida, 505 U. S. — (1992).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. -.
Michael W. Mason, Petitioner v. United States District
Court. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certio-
rari without paying the docket fee and/or without filing an affidavit in
support of a motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
-
No. Progress Engineering and Consulting Enterprise, Inc.,
Petitioner v. Ben Massongill. The motion of a non-attorney to direct the
Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari on behalf of a corporation
and in forma pauperis is denied.
No. Lisa Marie Stojanowski, Petitioner v. Metropolitan Gov-
ernment of Nashville and Davidson County, Tennessee. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is
denied.
-
No. Joan Mulligan Harvill, Petitioner v. Marion Dale Harvill.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time is denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
rect the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is

No. . E.S., Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed by peti-
tioner is denied.
No. A-154. Richard H. Thom, Applicant v. United States, et al. The
application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-157. Alexis Chan Heung-Kong, Applicant v. Wayne H. Sei-
fert, Warden. The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-174. Dsepine Smalis, Applicant v. Court of Common Pleas
Bail Agency. The application for a certificate of probable cause ad-
dressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-212. Alexis Chan Heung-Kong, Applicant v. Wayne H. Sei-
fert, Warden. The application for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-1121. In the Matter of Frank Ragano. Frank Ragano, of
Tampa, Florida, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of
this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attor-
neys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to
Show Cause, heretofore issued on May 18, 1992, is hereby discharged.
No. D-1126. In the Matter of Disbarment of John T. Martin. The mo-
tion to defer consideration is denied. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1134. In the Matter of Robert Yutaka Kimura. Robert Yuta-
ka Kimura, of Honolulu, Hawaii, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from
the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on June 8, 1992, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-1143. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mitchell King Byrd. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The Final Report of the River Master for Accounting Year 1991 is re-
ceived and ordered filed.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion of the Special Master for award of interim fees and re-
imbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master is awarded
a total of $244,063.47 to be paid as follows: 40% by Kansas, 40% by Col-
orado and 20% by the United States.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
5
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. State of Wyoming,
et al. The motion of Wyoming for leave to file a reply brief is granted.
The Exceptions to the Reports of the Special Master are set for oral
argument in due course.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of Midwest Securities Trust Company, et al. for leave to file
a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Securities Industries
Association, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
The motion of Delaware for leave to file a brief in reply to briefs of the
Texas Group Intervenors is granted. The motion of New York for leave
to file a reply brief is granted. The motion of Massachusetts for leave to
file a complaint in intervention is granted. The Exceptions to the Re-
port of the Special Master are set for oral argument in due course.
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The Answer of New Hampshire to the complaint of the utility.
intervenors is referred to the Special Master. Justice Souter took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 90-114. Consolidation Coal Company, Petitioner v. Director, Of-
fice of Workers' Compensation Programs, United States Department of
Labor, et al. The motion of respondent Albert C. Dayton for the award
of attorneys' fees is denied without prejudice to refiling in the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 91-155. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc.,
and Brian Rumbaugh, Petitioners v. Walter Lee; and
No. 91–339. Walter Lee, Superintendent of Port Authority Police,
Petitioner v. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc., et
al. The motion of respondent Walter Lee to retax costs is denied.
No. 91–261. Building and Construction Trades Council of the Metro-
politan District, Petitioner v. Associated Builders and Contractors of
Massachusetts/Rhode Island, Inc., et al.; and
No. 91-274. Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Associated Builders and Contractors of Massachusetts/Rhode
Island, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 91-522. Saudi Arabia, King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Roy-
spec, Petitioners v. Scott Nelson, et ux. The motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
for divided argument is granted. The motion of Human Rights Watch
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Inter-
national Human Rights Law Group, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 91-538. Forsyth County, Georgia, Petitioner v. Nationalist
Movement. The motion of petitioner to permit late filing of response to
motion for attorneys fees is granted. The motion of respondent for at-
torney fees is denied.
No. 91-610. Local 144 Nursing Home Pension Fund, et al., Petitioners
v. Nicholas Demisay, et al. The motion of petitioners to substitute Frank
Russo, et al., etc. in place of Peter Ottley, deceased, and John Kelley,
et al., etc. is granted. The motion of Western Conference of Teamsters
Pension Trust Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of National Coordinating Committee for Multiemployer
Plans for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of
Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Health and Welfare
Pension Funds et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 91-687. Montana, Petitioner v. Donald Glenn Imlay. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is
granted. The motion for appointment of counsel nunc pro tunc is
granted and it is ordered that Billy B. Miller, Esquire, of Great Falls,
Montana, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this
case. The motion of petitioner to strike supplemental brief of respond-
ent is denied.
No. 91-790. CSX Transportation, Inc., Petitioner v. Lizzie Beatrice
Easterwood; and
No. 91-1206. Lizzie Beatrice Easterwood, Petitioner v. CSX Trans-
portation, Inc. The motion of respondent/cross-petitioner to permit
Tambra Pannell Colston, Esq., to present oral argument pro hac vice is
granted. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
Justice Blackmun would deny this motion.
No. 91-794. Henry Harper, et al., Petitioners v. Virginia Depart-
ment of Taxation. The motion of Tax Executives Institute, Inc. for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 91-904. Concrete Pipe and Products of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Construction Laborers Pension Trust For Southern Califor-
nia. The motion of Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted. The motion of National Coordinating Committee for Multi-

7
employer Plans for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension
Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 91–1160. A. J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Thomas E. Creech.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Cliff Gardner, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 91-1188. James Rowland, Former Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Petitioners o. California Men's Colony, Unit
II Men's Adv. Council. The motion of respondent to direct the Clerk to
print respondent's supplemental brief is granted.
No. 91-1300. United States, Petitioner v. Sharon Dunnigan. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it
is ordered that Brent E. Beveridge, Esquire, of Fairmont, West Vir-
ginia, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 91-1306. United States, Petitioner v. Guy W. Olano, Jr., and
Raymond M. Gray. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted
and it is ordered that Carter G. Phillips, Esquire, of Washington, D.
C., is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent Guy W. Olano,
Jr. in this case. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit William
K. Kelley, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 91-1353. Thomas F. Conroy, Petitioner v. Walter Aniskoff, Jr.,
et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1496. Peter C. Reiter, et al., Petitioners v. Langdon M. Coo-
per, etc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 91-1526. Ferris J. Alexander, Sr., Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of petitioner for leave to enlarge questions presented for
review is denied.
No. 91-1600. Hazen Paper Company, et al., Petitioners v. Walter F.
Biggins. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1618. George Voinovich, Governor of Ohio, et al., Appellants
v. Barney Quilter, Speaker Pro Tempore of Ohio House of Represent-
atives, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1992
The motion of the Solicitor General to permit Thomas G. Hungar, Es-
quire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 91-1950. American Dredging Company, Petitioner v. William
Robert Miller. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 91-1958. Donald L. Helling, et al., Petitioners v. William McKin-
ney. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1970. Kalitta Flying Service, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. G.S.
Rasmussen & Associates, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 91–1992. Michael Figures, et al., Appellants v. Guy Hunt, Gov-
ernor of Alabama, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 91-5397. Emery L. Negonsott, Petitioner v. Harold Samuels,
Warden, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 91-7328. Leonel Torres Herrera, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion for appointment of counsel nunc pro tunc is granted and it
is ordered that Mark Olive, Esquire, of Tallahassee, Florida, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 91-7358. Todd A. Brecht, Petitioner v. Gordon A. Abrahamson,

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1992
129
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-7800. Felipe Epitacio Chew-Villasana, Petitioner v. Immigra-
tion and Naturalization Service. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for
further consideration in light of the decision in Texas v. Felipe Chew
(County Court of Duval County, February 26, 1992).
No. 92-26. Eldon S. Reed, Petitioner v. Victoria C. Drummond,
Trustee. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Patterson v. Shumate, 504 U. S. ——— (1992).
-
No. 92-90. Virtual Maintenance, Inc., Petitioner v. Prime Computer,
Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Eastman Kodak Company v. Image Technical Services, Inc., 504
U. S. (1992).
-
No. 92–203. Arkansas-Platte & Gulf Partnership, Petitioner v. Dow
Chemical Company, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Cipollone v. Liggett Group, Inc.,
505 U. S. - — (1992).
-

No. D-1142. In the Matter of Robert William Shaughnessy. Robert
William Shaughnessy, of Miami, Florida, having requested to resign as
a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on June 29,
1992, is hereby discharged.
No. D-1148. In the Matter of John P. Trevaskis, Jr. It having been
reported to the Court by John Rogers Carroll, of Media, Pennsylvania,
that John P. Trevaskis, Jr. has died, the Rule to Show Cause, hereto-
fore issued on August 18, 1992, is hereby discharged.
No. D-1166. In the Matter of Disbarment of David L. Brodsky. It is
ordered that David L. Brodsky, of Clive, Iowa, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that John L. Boettner Jr., of Charleston, West Virginia, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Carl M. Mitchell, of Hauppauge, New York, be suspended

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1992
No. 91-1206. Lizzie Beatrice Easterwood, Petitioner v. CSX Trans-

Kelley, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.

et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 92-74. Department of Revenue of Oregon, Petitioner v. ACF In-
dustries, Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 92-5505. Thomas G. Dean, Petitioner v. Ellen Smith, et al. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until November 3, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dissent-
ing: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S.
928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 92-5542. Robert Hudson, Petitioner v. New York. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until November 3, 1992, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 92-5794. Larry Cottam, Petitioner v. Luzerne County Children
and Youth Services. The application for stay addressed to Justice
O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.

peals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 92-5800. Kathleen H. Gamble, Petitioner v. Eau Claire County,
Wisconsin, et al. Petition for a writ of certiorari before judgment to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1992
151
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 92-326. In Re Jessie D. McDonald, Petitioner;
No. 92-5527. In Re Jules Smith, Petitioner;
No. 92-5564. In Re Carlton Walker, Petitioner; and
,
No. 92-5596. In Re William C. Ellis, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
mandamus denied.
No. 92-265. In Re Daniel Vasquez, Warden and Daniel Lungren, At-
torney General of California, Petitioners. Petition for a writ of manda-
mus is dismissed as moot.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Pow-
ell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit on September 28 and 30, 1992, and for
such time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant
to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this
Court, nunc pro tunc, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 19, 1992, until
Monday, November 2, 1992.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1992

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, and
Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1633. Sherman Hatcher, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Henry
Deutscher. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Sawyer v. Whitley, 505 U. S.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
(1992).
No. Robert N. Moreland, et ux., Petitioners v. Velsicol Chemi-
cal Corporation. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
-
No. Harold Amos Barnard, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit
of indigency executed by the petitioner is granted.

No. D-1176. In the Matter of Disbarment of Randy Wayne Keith. It
is ordered that Randy Wayne Keith, of Chatsworth, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1177. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arnold I. Biegen. It is
ordered that Arnold I. Biegen, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

dered that Morris Eisen, of New York, New York, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $14,388.53 for the period
April 1 June 30, 1992, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The motion of Nebraska for leave to file a sur-reply brief
is denied.

The motion of Thomas Gibson for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted.

stone Consolidated Industries, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General
to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-8674. John Angus Smith, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Gary
Kollin, Esquire, of Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 92-352. Jason W. Novak, et al., Petitioners v. Andersen Cor-
poration, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1992
179
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-6303. Ricky Lee Grubbs, Petitioner v. Paul Delo, Superin-
tendent, Potosi Correctional Center. The application for stay of execu-
tion of sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by him re-
ferred to the Court is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. The
order heretofore entered by Justice Blackmun is vacated. Dissenting
statement by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting statement by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting statement by Justice Souter.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1992
181
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-6260. John Sterling Gardner, Jr., Petitioner v. Gary Dixon,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay.
No. 92-6314. John Sterling Gardner, Jr., Petitioner v. Gary Dixon,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1992
183
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM
No. 92-5584. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. District of Columbia
Court of Appeals, et al.; and
No. 92-5618. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Christine McDermott,
et al. On motions of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis.
Motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. See Rule 39.8.
Petitioner allowed until November 23, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38 and to submit petitions in compliance
with Rule 33. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 92-522. Joseph Gardner, et al., Appellants v. Illinois Legislative
Redistricting Commission, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Illinois. The judgment is
affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1993. Continental Casualty Company, Petitioner v. Fibre-
board Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to consider
the question of mootness.
No. 92-5152. William Frederick Happ, Petitioner v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Espinosa v. Florida, 505 U. S. (1992).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1090. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald J. Garner. The
motion to reconsider the disbarment order is denied.
No. D-1160. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph Hilliard Weil.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1161. In the Matter of Curtis Larenzo Jones, Jr. Curtis La-
renzo Jones, Jr., of Miami, Florida, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 4,
1992, is hereby discharged.
No. D-1191. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas J. Skryd. It is
ordered that Thomas J. Skryd, of Cicero, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

dered that Bennett Alban, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1992
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition

See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until November 23, 1992, within

Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari.
No. 92-5828. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Widener University
School of Law, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until No-
vember 23, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ
of certiorari.
No. 92-5899. Edith C. Wade, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et
al. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioners are allowed until November 23, 1992, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.

fonso Sota, Petitioners v. United States. Argued by Mr. Kenneth L.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1992
215
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 92–478. Arizona Hispanic Community Forum, Appellant v. J.
Fife Symington, Governor of Arizona, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Arizona. The judgment is af-
firmed. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-86. J. L. Sivley, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Carlos Soler.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with directions to dismiss.
United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U. S. 36 (1950).
No. 92-485. Sean O'Keefe, Acting Secretary of the Navy, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Arlen Specter, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
for further consideration in light of Franklin v. Massachusetts, 505
U. S. (1992).

barment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1992
No. D-1162. In the Matter of Disbarment of T. Jay Salmen. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1164. In the Matter of Disbarment of Phillip Frascinella. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1201. In the Matter of Disbarment of Reginald L. Norris. It is
ordered that Reginald L. Norris, of Grand Rapids, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1202. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard Leighton. It is
ordered that Leonard Leighton, of San Antonio, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1203. In the Matter of Disbarment of Don Michael Baucum. It
is ordered that Don Michael Baucum, of San Antonio, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1204. In the Matter of Disbarment of Franklin R. Sears. It is
ordered that Franklin R. Sears, of Fort Worth, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1205. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hubert Phil Isaacks. It
is ordered that Hubert Phil Isaacks, of Odessa, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motions for additional time for oral argument and for divided argu-
ment are granted in part and denied in part. An additional ten minutes
are allotted for oral argument. The time for oral argument is divided as
follows: twenty minutes for Delaware; twenty minutes for New York;
and thirty minutes for one attorney in support of the Report of the Spe-
cial Master.
No. 91–10. Spectrum Sports, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley
McQuillan, et vir, dba Sorboturf Enterprises. The motion of respond-
ents for leave to file a supplemental joint appendix is granted.

No. 91–719. Al C. Parke, Warden, Petitioner v. Ricky Harold Raley.
The motion of Criminal Justice Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief

pauperis is denied.

proceed in forma pauperis is denied.

Idaho Department of Water Resources. The motion of the Solicitor
General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 92-443. James M. Elfelt, et al., Petitioners v. Albina Cooper.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 92-5988. John A. Anderson, Petitioner v. Wisconsin Department
of Revenue. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 30, 1992, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant certiorari.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-259. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Sac and Fox
Nation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 92-621. Donald Neal Rake, et al., Petitioners v. William J.
Wade, Trustee. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 91-8685. Terry Lynn Stinson, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition

218
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1992
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit granted limited to the following question: "Whether a
court's failure to follow Sentencing Guidelines commentary that gives
specific direction that the offense of unlawful possession of a firearm by
a felon is not a crime of violence under USSG Section 4B1.1, see USSG
Section 4B1.2 comment. (n.2), constitutes an 'incorrect application of
the sentencing guidelines' under 18 U. S. C. Section 3742(f)(1)."

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1992
237
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and
Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1328. City of Chicago, et al., Petitioners v. Environmental
Defense Fund, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for fur-
ther consideration in light of the memorandum of the Administrator of
the Environmental Protection Agency, dated September 18, 1992, re-
garding Exemption for Municipal Waste Combustion Ash From Haz-
ardous Waste Regulation Under RCRA Section 3001(i).
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Donald Flynn, Petitioner v. Michigan, et al. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a complaint is denied.
No. D-1150. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald E. Deutsch. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1153. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert L. Kirkman.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1155. In the Matter of Disbarment of Segundo Unpingco. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1159. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas George Brodo.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1163. In the Matter of Disbarment of David R. Knoll. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1206. In the Matter of Disbarment of Calvin W. Breit. It is
ordered that Calvin W. Breit, of Virginia Beach, Virginia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

238
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1992
No. D-1207. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fred I. Zabriskie. It is
ordered that Fred I. Zabriskie, of Larchmont, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for award of compensation and re-
imbursement of expenses is granted and the River Master is awarded
$8,082.13 for the period July 1 - September 30, 1992, to be paid equally
by the parties.
No. 91-8258. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Delaware. The motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied.
No. 91-8729. John B. Dempsey, Petitioner v. Sears, Roebuck & Co.,
et al. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 92-479. TXO Production Corp., Petitioner v. Alliance Resources
Corp., et al. The motion of American Petroleum Institute, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of West Vir-
ginia Chamber of Commerce for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 92-5068. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Gilchrist Sparks, et al.
The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 92-5938. In Re Fred Whitaker. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner
is allowed until December 7, 1992, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens would deny the petition for a writ of prohibition.
No. 92-6036. Mason Ford, Petitioner v. United States. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until December 7, 1992, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), I
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

States, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment of the Court of Appeals is va-

this opinion. Opinion by Justice Stevens announced by The Chief
Justice.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per
curiam announced by The Chief Justice.

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1992
255
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-6391. Jeffrey L. Griffin, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.

No. 92-6622. Jeffrey L. Griffin, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.

Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay of execution.

for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.

No. A-400. Cornelius Singleton, Applicant v. Morris Thigpen, Com-

by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1992
261
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1766. Church of Scientology of California, Petitioner v.
United States and Frank S. Zolin. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Church of Scientology v. United
States, 506 U. S. (1992).
No.
-.

tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by the petitioner is granted.

motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-
time, is denied.

of Health and Human Services. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.

suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The motion of the Special Master for compensation and
reimbursement of expenses is granted and it is ordered that the Special
Master is awarded a total of $124,171.27 for the period March 1, 1992,
through October 15, 1992, to be paid as follows: 20% by the United
States and 40% each by Nebraska and Wyoming.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. The motion of the Special Master for compensation and
reimbursement of expenses is granted and it is ordered that the Special
Master is awarded a total of $64,112.96 for the period November 1,
1991, through September 23, 1992, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 91-8581. Jessie D. McDonald, Petitioner v. Yellow Cab Metro,
Inc. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.

Association, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.

to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1992
forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until De-

and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-719. Al C. Parke, Warden, Petitioner v. Ricky Harold Raley.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-7094. Willie Lee Richmond, Petitioner v. Samuel A. Lewis,
Director, Arizona Department of Corrections, et al. On writ of to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1992
297
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-586. Fund for Accurate and Informed Representation, Inc.,
et al., Appellants v. Saul Weprin, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of New York. The judgment is
affirmed. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Romanus Ngene-Igwe, Petitioner v. Iowa State Univer-
sity, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-313. Donna Luann Lovett, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-1170. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Sandberg. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1171. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Dennis Simon.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1216. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fredric G. Hayes. It is
ordered that Fredric G. Hayes, of Lafayette, Louisiana, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The motions of the parties respecting oral argument are
granted in part and denied in part and the time and the order allotted
are: 20 minutes to Wyoming, 10 minutes to Colorado, 15 minutes to Ne-
braska, and 15 minutes to the United States.
No. 91–261. Building and Construction Trades Council of the Metro-
politan District, Petitioner v. Associated Builders and Contractors of
Massachusetts/Rhode Island, Inc., et al.; and

298
MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1992
No. 91–274. Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Associated Builders and Contractors of Massachusetts/Rhode
Island, Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file
supplemental brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 91-1671. William J. Mertens, Alex W. Bandrowski, James A.
Clark, and Russell Franz, Petitioners v. Hewitt Associates. The motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1738. Jerry D. Gilmore, Petitioner v. Kevin Taylor. The mo-
tion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Law-
rence C. Marshall, Esquire, of Chicago, Illinois, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 91–7604. Jeffery Antoine, Petitioner v. Byers & Anderson, Inc.,
et al. The motion of Jonathan and Karen Scott for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 92-94. Larry Zobrest, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Catalina Foot-
hills School District. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted.
No. 92-5618. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Christine McDermott,
et al.; and
No. 92-5828. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Widener University
School of Law, et al. The motions of petitioner for reconsideration of
orders denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis are denied.
No. 92-6265. Pamela Dock, Petitioner v. American Telephone & Tel-
egraph Technologies, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December
28, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 92-6281. Robert Hagen, Petitioner v. Utah. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 92-6378. Kamal B. Mahdavi, Petitioner v. The Regents of the
University of California. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1992
299
in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until
December 28, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ
of certiorari.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 92-357. Ruth O. Shaw, et al., Appellants v. William Barr, Attor-
ney General, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of North Carolina. In this case probable jurisdiction is
noted. Argument shall be limited to the following question, which all
parties are directed to brief: "Whether a state legislature's intent to
comply with the Voting Rights Act and the Attorney General's inter-
pretation thereof precludes a finding that the legislature's congres-
sional redistricting plan was adopted with invidious discriminatory in-
tent where the legislature did not accede to the plan suggested by the
Attorney General but instead developed its own."
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92–641. Leonard Nobelman, et ux., Petitioners v. American Sav-
ings Bank, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.

nois, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1992
319
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today we take note of the retirement of William Fender of the
Supreme Court Police Force, effective December 31 of this year. Cor-
poral Fender has been a member of our police force for over thirty-one
years and during those years he has attended virtually every session of
Court in his official capacity to help maintain order. Over those years,
he has earned the respect of the members of the Bar who practice regu-
larly before this Bench. The Court wishes him well on his retirement."

No. 92-6873. Kavin Lincecum, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1992
321
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-6882. Timothy D. Bunch, Petitioner v. Willis B. Wright,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1992

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and
Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-443. R. D. and J. D., Applicants v. D. S. The application for
stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the Court is denied.

Disbarment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

barment order entered.
No. D-1182. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph P. Napoli. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1183. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jean D. Artman. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1217. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel P. Glecier. It is
ordered that Daniel P. Glecier, of Lompoc, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1218. In the Matter of Disbarment of Herman Arthur Ham-
mel. It is ordered that Herman Arthur Hammel, of Joliet, Illinois, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

fornia, et al.; and

of Washington. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until January 4,
1993, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari.

OPINIONS
No. 91-990. Dale Farrar and Pat Smith, Co-Administrators of of Es-
tate of Joseph D. Farrar, deceased, Petitioners v. William P. Hobby,
Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice White concurring
in part and dissenting in part in which Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Souter join.
No. 91-1326. The District of Columbia and Sharon Pratt Kelly,
Mayor, Petitioners v. The Greater Washington Board of Trade. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1992
337
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-767. Republic National Bank of Miami, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment is reversed and the case is remanded
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice Blackmun announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, and IV, and an
opinion with respect to Part III in which Justice Stevens and Justice
O'Connor join. The Chief Justice delivered the opinion of the Court in
part and, joined by Justice White, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Souter, concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Con-
curring opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Stevens concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Thomas
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-1158. Mississippi, et al., Petitioners v. Louisiana, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief
Justice.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1993
345
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-602. St. Mary's Honor Center, et al., Petitioners v. Melvin
Hicks. The petition for a writ of certiorari to United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. The brief of the petitioners
must be received by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3:00 p.m., February 22, 1993. The brief of the respondent must
be received by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3:00 p.m., March 24, 1993. A reply brief, if any, must be received by the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., April
12, 1993. Rule 29 does not apply. The case is set for oral argument dur-
ing the Session beginning April 19; 1993.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1993
347
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-837. Rafel Lopez, Appellant v. Hale County, Texas, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Texas. The judgment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1141. Robyn Price and Robert Carter, Petitioners v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United States,
506 U. S.
-
(1992).
No. 91-1720. Jesus Jose Castro-Vasquez and Luz Marlene Castro,
Petitioners v. United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Republic National Bank of Miami
v. United States, 506 U. S. (1992).
-
No. 91-1884. Cesar Tangonan and Rosario Tangonan, Petitioners v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United
States, 506 U. S. (1992).
No. 92-511. Stevedoring Services of America, Petitioner v. Ancora
Transport, N.V., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United

348
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1993
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United
States, 506 U. S. (1992).
-
No. 92-6031. Alfred Octave Morrill, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of the position asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the
United States filed November 25, 1992.
,
No. 92-6239. Ricky Lee Price, Petitioner v. North Carolina. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Morgan v. Illinois, 504 U. S. — (1992).

No. D-1219. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward William Babic.
It is ordered that Edward William Babic, of Newport Beach, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1220. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan C. Sugarman. It is
ordered that Alan C. Sugarman, of Boca Raton, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that David Brice Toy, of Los Angeles, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 92-725. Salvador Godinez, Warden, Petitioner v. Richard Allan
Moran. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is or-
dered that Cal J. Potter, III, Esquire, of Las Vegas, Nevada, is ap-

of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied.
No. 92-6171. Sylvester Jones, Petitioner v. Thomas Penfield Jack-
son, Judge, United States District Court for the District of Columbia,
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until February 1, 1993,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari.
No. 92-6443. In Re John T. Fowler, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until February 1, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court.
No. 92-6493. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. Supreme Court
of Washington. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until February
1, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition.
for a writ of certiorari.

No. 92-6839. German Moreno, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 92-373. Tim Roche, Petitioner v. Florida. The motion of peti-
tioner to enlarge the record is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District, denied.
No. 92-579. James Blodgett, et al., Petitioners v. Rogaciano
Gonzales Mendoza. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 92-606. Burlington Northern Railroad Company, Petitioner v.
Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, et al. The motion of
Association of American Railroads, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 92-610. Roy E. Sherman, Petitioner v. William F. Ludington, et
al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 92-6157. Malcolm Frazier, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1993
379
No. 92-784. Oklahoma Coalition to Restrict Abortion, Inc. and Fred
W. Sellers, Jr., Petitioners v. Nancy Feldman and Kim Little. The mo-
tion of Oklahoma for leave to intervene is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oklahoma denied.
No. 92-817. Soldier of Fortune Magazine, Inc. and Omega Group,
Ltd., Petitioners v. Michael F. Braun and Ian Braun. The motion of Na-
tional Association for Information Services for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of National Rifle Association of
America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 92-948. Coy Ray Phelps, Petitioner v. Peter Carlson, Warden,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 92-5850. Krishna Maharaj, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari limited to Question 3 presented by the
petition.
No. 92-5862. Daryl James Faulkenberry, Petitioner v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice White and Justice O'Connor
would grant certiorari.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 92-6866. In Re Billy Lloyd Edwards Punchard, Petitioner; and
No. 92-6908. In Re Bernard Dickerson, Petitioner. Petitions for
writs of habeas corpus denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 92-867. In Re Earlene Polyak, Petitioner; and
No. 92-6318. In Re Robert Peter Russell, Petitioner. Petitions for
writs of mandamus denied.
No. 92-6442. In Re Paris Valentine, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
mandamus and/or prohibition denied.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Pow-
ell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit from November 30, 1992, through June
11, 1993, and for such time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92-7213. Antonio N. Bonham, Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is granted pending disposition
by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition
for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In
the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall
continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91–1188. James Rowland, Former Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. California Men's Colony, Unit
II Men's Adv. Council. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Thomas in which Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 91-998. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Nader
E. Soliman. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas concurring in the judgment in which Justice Scalia joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-871. Bath Iron Works Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Di-
rector, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, etc., et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-1010. Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority, Petitioner
v. Metcalf and Eddy, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens.

No. 90-985. Jayne Bray, et al., Petitioners v. Alexandria Women's
Health Clinic, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, vacated in
part and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in the judgment in
part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens in
which Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor
in which Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 91-6194.-Michael Crosby, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 91-740.-Walter L. Nixon, Petitioner v. United States, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice
White concurring in the judgment in which Justice Blackmun joins.
Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in the judgment.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1993
403
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, State of Massachusetts and
State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. New Hampshire. The Report of the
Special Master is received and ordered filed. Exceptions to the Report,
with supporting briefs, may be filed by the parties. Such exceptions
must be received by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3:00 p.m., March 1, 1993. Reply briefs, if any, must be received
by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m.,
March 31, 1993. Rule 29 does not apply. The case is set for oral argu-
ment during the Session beginning April 19, 1993. Justice Souter took
no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-6033. William McNeil, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit are granted. The brief of the petitioner must be re-
ceived by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00
p.m., March 1, 1993. The brief of the respondent must be received by
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m.,
March 31, 1993. A reply brief, if any, must be received by the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., April 12, 1993.
Rule 29 does not apply. The case is set for oral argument during the
Session beginning April 19, 1993.
No. 92-6073. Richard Lyle Austin, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit are granted. The brief of the petitioner must be re-
ceived by the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00
p.m., March 1, 1993. The brief of the respondent must be received by
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m.,
March 31, 1993. A reply brief, if any, must be received by the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., April 12, 1993.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
