The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
PER CURIAM
No. 92-5579. Wilburn Dobbs, Petitioner v. Walter D. Zant, Warden.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and the petition for a writ of certiorari are granted.
Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Opinion
by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment in which Justice Thomas.
joins. Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justice White would grant certiorari
and give the case plenary consideration.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92–217. American Council of the Blind of Colorado, Inc., etc., et
al., Petitioners v. Roy Romer, Governor of Colorado, et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Far-
rar v. Hobby, 506 U. S. (1992).
No. 92–292. Ronald Kolodzieczak, et al., Petitioners v. Jack Wayne
Friend, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Farrar v. Hobby, 506 U. S. - (1992).
No. 92-402. Robert Nichols, et al., Petitioners v. Michael Romberg,
et ux. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the

disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Simpson, et al. in this case.

No. 92-6027. Carlton Smith, Petitioner v. Marvin T. Runyon, Post-
master General, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until February 9, 1993,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

408
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1993
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 92-6449. Dorothy L. Davis, Petitioner v. Marvin T. Runyon,
Postmaster General, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until February 9,
1993, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown
v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for
a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed.
in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI DENIED

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-7300. Charles S. Stamper, Petitioner v. Ellis B. Wright, Jr.,

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1993
425
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and
Justice Thomas.
The Court convened at 10:00 a.m. in the West Conference Room and
the Chief Justice said:
"The Court will take a recess to attend the inauguration of the Presi-
dent of the United States."
The Court adjourned to the restored Supreme Court chamber at the
Capitol to robe. The oath of office was administered to Vice President
Gore by Justice White. The oath of office was administered to President
Clinton by the Chief Justice. The Marshal adjourned the Court until
Monday, January 25, 1993, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1993
427
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Con-
nor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice
Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"As we open this morning, I announce with sadness that our friend
and colleague Thurgood Marshall, a former Justice of this Court, died.
yesterday, January 24, 1993, at the National Naval Medical Center, Be-
thesda, Maryland.
Born in Baltimore, Maryland in 1908, Thurgood Marshall was the
grandson of a Union soldier, his namesake, and a great-grandson of a
slave. His father worked as a dining-car waiter and a chief steward at a
segregated club, and early instilled in his son the urge to question the
legal status of minorities in this country. His mother taught school for
over three decades and devoted herself to her two sons while they were
growing up. Justice Marshall worked his way through Lincoln Univer-
sity and excelled at Howard University Law School under the tutelage
of Charles Houston.
After a brief period in solo practice in Baltimore, Justice Marshall
joined the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, eventually be-
coming its special counsel and, later, its director. The most influential
civil rights lawyer of this century, Justice Marshall designed and imple-
mented the NAACP's legal strategy to eradicate racial discrimination
in education, transportation, housing, and the voting booth. In court-
houses across the country, he became the champion of equal opportu-
nity for minorities. As an advocate, Justice Marshall won 29 cases be-
fore this Court, including the landmark Brown v. Board of Education.
He left the NAACP when President Kennedy appointed him to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in 1961. In 1965,
President Johnson named him Solicitor General and, two years later,
appointed him an Associate Justice of this Court.
Justice Marshall's contributions to constitutional law before his ap-
pointment to this Court were singular. These contributions alone would
entitle him to a prominent place in American history had he never
served on this Court. Building on those earlier accomplishments, he be-
came an important voice in shaping the decisional law during his
twenty-four years on the Supreme Court bench.
The members of this Court will miss Justice Marshall's wit, warmth
and charm, and I speak for them in expressing our profound sympathy

428
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1993
to Mrs. Marshall, her sons Thurgood and John, the remainder of the
Marshall family, and all those whose lives were touched by this extraor-
dinary man. The recess this Court takes today will be in his memory.
At an appropriate time, the traditional memorial observance of the
Court and the Bar of the Court will be held in this Courtroom."
OPINIONS
No. 91-1421. United States, Petitioner v. William F. Hill, et ux. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
No. 91-6824. Gloria Zafiro, Joe Martinez, Salvador Garcia and Al-
fonso Soto, Petitioners v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in the judgment.
No. 91-10. Spectrum Sports, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley
McQuillan, et vir, dba Sorboturf Enterprises. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
No. 91-7580. Gary Graham, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by
Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Souter in which Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens
and Justice O'Connor join.

ternal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

White.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92-7351. Ramon Montoya, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal
Appeals of Texas. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied,
this stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ
of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the issuance of
the mandate of this Court.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-7328. Martsay Bolder, Petitioner v. Bill Armontrout, War-
den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Souter would grant the stay of execution.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-7380. Martsay Bolder, Petitioner v. Paul Delo, Superintend-
ent, Potosi Correctional Center. The application for stay of execution of
sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to
the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is denied.

No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The Supplement to the Final Report of the Special Master is re-
ceived and ordered filed. Exceptions to this Report, with supporting
briefs, are to be included in the Exceptions referenced in the order of
January 15, 1993. Such Exceptions must be received by the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., Monday, March
15, 1993. Reply briefs, if any, are to be included in the reply briefs ref-
erenced in the order of January 15, 1993. Such reply briefs are to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00
p.m., Wednesday, April 7, 1993. Rule 29 does not apply. The case is set
for oral argument during the Session beginning April 19, 1993. Justice
Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.

Corporation et al. The motion of the parties to defer oral argument is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-5653. Dorsie Lee Johnson, Jr., Petitioner v. Texas. On peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is limited to Question 1
presented by the petition. The brief of petitioner is to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., Mon-
day, March 22, 1993. The brief of respondent is to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., Mon-
day, April 12, 1993. A reply brief, if any, is to be filed with the Clerk
and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3:00 p.m., Thursday,
April 22, 1993. The case is set for oral argument on Monday, April 26,
1993. Rule 29 does not apply in this case.

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 92-609. United States, Petitioner v. Jerry J. Nachtigal. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment
is reversed and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

Women's Health Clinic, 506 U. S.- — (1993).

forma pauperis.

No. 92-519. T. K. Wetherell, Speaker of the Florida House of Repre-
sentatives, et al., Appellants v. Miguel De Grandy, et al.;
No. 92–593. Miguel De Grandy, et al., Appellants v. T. K. Wetherell,
Speaker of the Florida House of Representatives, et al.; and
No. 92-767. United States, Appellant v. Florida, et al. Appeals from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida.
The motion of American Jewish Congress, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae in No. 92-519 is granted. In these cases probable juris-
diction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is
allotted for oral argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-1123. Izumi Seimitsu Kogyo Kabushiki Kaisha, Petitioner v.
U. S. Philips Corporation, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted.
No. 91-1523. Florence County School District Four, et al., Petition-
ers v. Shannon Carter, a minor by and through her father, and next
friend, Emory D. Carter. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 1 presented by the petition.
No. 92-757. Barbara Landgraf, Petitioner v. USI Film Products, et
al.; and
No. 92-938. Maurice Rivers and Robert C. Davison, Petitioners v.
Roadway Express, Inc. In No. 92-757, petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted lim-
ited to Question 1 presented by the petition. In No. 92-938, petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit is granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.

No. 92-6696. Joseph Taylor, Petitioner v. City of New Albany, et al.
Petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 92-732. Gulf States Steel, Inc. of Alabama, Petitioner v. LTV
Corporation, et al. The motion of Alabama to intervene or in the alter-
native, to file a brief amicus curiae denied. Petition for rehearing is
denied.
No. 92-5505. Thomas G. Dean, Petitioner v. Ellen Smith, et al. The
motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing denied.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1993
511
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91–321. Itel Containers International Corporation, Petitioner v.
Joe Huddleston, Commissioner of Revenue of Tennessee. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Scalia,
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Blackmun.
No. 91-1300. United States, Petitioner v. Sharon Dunnigan. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
No. 91-1420. Joan Growe, Secretary of State of Minnesota, et al.,
Appellants v. James Emison, et al. On appeal to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Minnesota. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of Minne-
sota with instructions to dismiss. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 91–7873. William Fex, Petitioner v. Michigan. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Jus-
tice Stevens joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

OPINIONS
No. 91–781. United States, Petitioner v. A Parcel of Land, Buildings,
Appurtenances and Improvements, Known as 92 Buena Vista Avenue,
Rumson, New Jersey, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice Ste-
vens announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in
which Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor and Justice Souter join.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Thomas joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Chief
Justice Rehnquist and Justice White join.

Warden, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join all but Part II-B
of this opinion.

515
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 92-1194. Peter Holloway, et al., Appellants v. Ken Hechler, Sec-
retary of State of West Virginia, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia. The judg-
ment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-856. Joseph J. Ponte, Superintendent, Massachusetts Correc-
tional Institute at Walpole, et al., Petitioners v. Dennis J. Domegan.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consideration in light
of Farrar v. Hobby, 506 U. S. (1992).
No. 92-982. Joseph A. Mohwish, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position presently asserted by the Acting Solicitor General in his brief
for the United States filed February 5, 1993.
No.

and Telegraph Company, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration of decision of this motion.
No. Ysidro L. Gradillas, Petitioner v. City of Rancho Mirage.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time is denied.

No. D-1217. In the Matter of of Daniel P. Glecier. Daniel P. Glecier,
of Lompoc, California, having requested to resign as a member of the
Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll
of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule
to Show Cause, heretofore issued on December 14, 1992, is hereby
discharged.

mel. Disbarment order entered.

barment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

ordered that David Bruce Small, of Carson City, Nevada, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Michael Levi Matar, of Forest Hills, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

that Ira Postel, of New York, New York, be suspended from the prac-

days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.

peals for the Eleventh Circuit granted limited to the following question:
"Whether the Court of Appeals erred in holding that governance by a
single county commissioner, rather than a multi-member board of com-
missioners, is subject to challenge as dilutive under Section 2 of the
Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended, 42 U. S. C. Section 1973."

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-654. Samuel Lewis, Director, Arizona Department of Correc-
tions, et al., Applicants v. Elsie Brewer, as next friend of John George
Brewer. Application to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is
granted, and it is ordered that the order staying the execution entered
by Judge Norris of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit on March 2, 1993, is vacated. Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens would deny the application.
OPINIONS

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Sca-
lia and Justice Thomas join in all but Part IV-A of this opinion. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice White joins.

County Narcotics Intelligence and Coordination Unit, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1993
541
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 92-409. Paul Delo, Superintendent, Potosi Correctional Center,
Petitioner v. Frederick Lashley. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment is reversed and the case
is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Justice Souter joins only Part 1 of this opin-
ion. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Black-
mun joins.
No. 92-6846. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. Michael C.
Storrie, et al. On motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. See Rule
39.8. Petitioner is allowed until March 29, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38 and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-96. Patricia A. Mertens, Petitioner v. Wallace G. Wilkinson,
etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Kentucky. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment
is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky
for further consideration in light of Leatherman v. Tarrant County
Narcotics Intelligence and Coordination Unit, 507 U. S.
- _
- (1993).
No. 92-973. Harris County Appraisal District, et al., Petitioners v.
Transamerica Container Leasing, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Appeals of Texas, First District. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Texas, First District, for further consider-

542
MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1993
ation in light of Itel Containers International Corporation v. Huddles-
ton, 507 U. S. (1993). Justice Stevens would deny certiorari.
No. 92-5060. Colleen Sullivan, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of United States v. Dunnigan, 507 U. S. (1993).
No. 92-6558. George Curry Hudson, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United States, 506 U. S.
(1992).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-621. Irene M. Ibarra, etc., et al., Petitioner v. Duc Van Le,
etc. Application for stay presented to Justice White and by him re-
ferred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the judgment of the
Supreme Court of Colorado in case No. 91SC189 is stayed pending the
timely filing and disposition by this Court of a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay
terminates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of certio-
rari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the issuance of the man-
date of this Court.
No. D-1193. In the Matter of Disbarment of Terrance Leon
McGowan. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1199. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mitchell Wayne Kirk.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1214. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen Robert Bodell.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1245. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold Murray Cohen.
It is ordered that Harold Murray Cohen, of Secaucus, New Jersey, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1993
543
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. Motion of Special Master for award of fees and disbursements is
granted and the Special Master is awarded a total of $129,031 to be paid
as follows: Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island to each pay
$14,336.78 and New Hampshire and the intervening utilities to each
pay $43,010.33. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 92-311. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. Richard H. Schaefer. The motion of the Acting Solici-
tor General to permit William K. Kelley, Esquire, to present oral argu-
ment pro hac vice is granted.
No. 92-351. Leonard Heller, Secretary, Kentucky Cabinet for
Human Resources, Petitioner v. Samuel Doe, by his mother and next
friend, Mary Doe, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to file a reply
brief out-of-time is granted.
No. 92-1012. Simpson Paper (Vermont) Company, Petitioner v. De-
partment of Environmental Conservation and Sierra Club. The Solici-
tor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of
the United States.
No. 92-7241. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. Washington. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until March 29, 1993 within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
No. 92-7242. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner
is allowed until March 29, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.

Reich, Secretary of Labor, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.

OPINIONS
No. 91-1496. Peter C. Reiter, et al., Petitioners v. Langdon M. Coo-
per, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is re-

558
MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1993
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice Blackmun dissents.
No. 91-261. Building and Construction Trades Council of the Metro-
politan District, Petitioner v. Associated Builders and Contractors of
Massachusetts/Rhode Island. Inc., et al.; and
No. 91–274. Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Associated Builders and Contractors of Massachusetts/Rhode
Island, Inc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 91-7749. Jose Antonio Ortega-Rodriguez, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and the case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist with
whom Justice White, Justice O'Connor and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91-1538. Sandra Jean Smith, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.

Murray, Ellis B. Wright Jr., and John Doe. Application for stay of exe-
cution of sentence of death presented to the Chief Justice and by him
referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1993
569
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 92–362. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, et al., Appellants, v.
Arizonans for Fair Representation, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Arizona. The judgment is af-
firmed. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 92-1257. Hollis Watkins, et al., Appellants v. Kirk Fordice, Gov-
ernor of Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 92-1295. Kirk Fordice, Governor of Mississippi, et al., Appel-
lants v. Hollis Watkins, et al. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. The appeals are dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92–933. Americo Lopes, Trustee, Petitioner v. City of Peabody,
Massachusetts. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of Massachusetts. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals of Massachusetts for further consideration in light of Lucas v.
South Carolina Coastal Council, 505 U. S. (1992).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Francis X. Hopkins, Warden, Petitioner v. John E. Rust.
The motion of petitioner to dispense with printing portions of the ap-
pendix to the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-598. Steven D. Weiner, et al., Petitioners v. National City, et
al. The application for a stay pending filing and disposition of a petition
for writ of certiorari addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court is denied.

570
MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1993
No. D-1221. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Brice Toy. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1225. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles L. Gladson. Dis-
barment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

No. D-1246. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ellis S. Simring. It is
ordered that Ellis S. Simring, of Hollywood, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1247. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alvin Lamar Keel. It is
ordered that Alvin Lamar Keel, of Bingham Farms, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1248. In the Matter of Disbarment of Janice Marie Hayes. It
is ordered that Janice Marie Hayes, of Las Vegas, Nevada, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1249. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kathryn Ann Schinde-
lar. It is ordered that Kathryn Ann Schindelar, of Stanhope, New Jer-
sey, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why
she should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1250. In the Matter of Disbarment of Patrick D. Williams. It
is ordered that Patrick D. Williams, of Boulder, Colorado, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92–1274. Anago Incorporated, Petitioners v. Tecnol Medical
Products, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8060. Carlos Santana, Petitioner v. Texas. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Petition for a writ of certiorari to
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 92-8060. Carlos Santana, Petitioner v. Texas. Petition for re-
hearing is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 23, 1993
601
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8064. Carlos Santana, Petitioner v. Ann Richards, Governor
of Texas, et al. Application for stay of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit is denied.
OPINIONS
No. 91–522. Saudia Arabia, King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Roy-
spec, Petitioners v. Scott Nelson, et ux. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice
White, with whom Justice Blackmun joins, concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy, with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join as to
Parts I-B and II, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 91-905. Janet Reno, Attorney General, et al., Petitioners v.
Jenny Lisette Flores, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor with
whom Justice Souter joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Blackmun joins.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 92–166. Keene Corporation, Petitioner v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Richard G. Taranto for petitioner and by Mr. Lawrence G. Wal-
lace for respondent.
No. 91-8674. John Angus Smith, Petitioner v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Gary Kollin for petitioner and by Mr. Thomas G. Hungar for
respondent.
No. 92-259. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Sac and Fox
Nation. Argued by Mr. David Allen Miley for petitioner, by Mr. Edwin
S. Kneedler for the United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of
the Court, and by Mr. G. William Rice for respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 24, 1993
603
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-1229. United States by and through Internal Revenue Serv-
ice, Petitioner v. Bruce J. McDermott, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas with whom Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 91-1200. City of Cincinnati, Petitioner v. Discovery Network,
Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Chief
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice White and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91-1695. Pioneer Investment Services Company, Petitioner v.
Brunswick Associates Limited Partnership, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor with whom Justice Scalia, Justice Souter and Justice Thomas
join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1993
605
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Kenneth V. Hemmerle, Sr., Petitioner v. Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation as Receiver for Sunrise Savings & Loan Associ-
ation, etc., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to treat the notice of
appeal as a petition for a writ of certiorari and file the petition is denied.
No. A-446. Derrick Leon Hills, Petitioner v. United States. The ap-
plication for bond addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-1219. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward William Babic.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1251. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph D. J. Gourley. It
is ordered that Joseph D. J. Gourley, of Wayne, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92-6849. Rolf Betka, Petitioner v. A-T Industries, Inc., et al.
The motion for reconsideration of the order denying leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied.
No. 92-7589. Jim LaChance and Debbie LaChance, Petitioners v.
Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The motion of petitioners for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed
until April 19, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-1223. United States Department of Defense, et al., Petition-
ers v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted.

606
MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1993
No. 92–1292. Luther R. Campbell aka Luke Skywalker, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc. The motion of Capitol Steps Produc-
tions, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit granted limited to the following question: "Whether peti-
tioners' commercial parody was a 'fair use' within the meaning of 17
U. S. C. Section 107."

MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 92-1337. In Re Ronald L. Branson, Petitioner;
No. 92-7537. In Re Michael McKinzy, Petitioner; and

No. 92-747. Wm. F. McCollough, et ux., Petitioners v. A. G. Ed-
wards & Sons, Inc.;

poration, et al.;

No. 92-7027. Michael Henry Ferdik, Petitioner v. Grant Woods, At-
torney General of Arizona, et al.;
No. 92-7115. Darrell Wayne McAfee, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division;
and
No. 92-7175. Wilbert DeShields, Petitioner v. William J. Love, Su-
perintendent, State Correctional Institution at Huntingdon. Petitions
for rehearing are denied.
No. 92-948. Coy Ray Phelps, Petitioner v. Peter Carlson, Warden,
et al. Petition for rehearing is denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 92-6310. Mark George Somes, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to file a petition for rehearing is denied.

The Chief Justice said:
"The Court now recognizes the Acting Solicitor General, Mr. William
C. Bryson."
Acting Solicitor General William C. Bryson said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I have the honor to
present to the Court the Seventy-Eighth Attorney General of the
United States, The Honorable Janet Reno of Florida."
The Chief Justice said:
“General Reno, on behalf of the Court I welcome you as the Chief
Law Officer of the Government and as an officer of this Court. We wel-

620
MONDAY, MARCH 29, 1993
come you to the performance of your very important duties which will
rest upon you by virtue of your office. Your commisssion as Attorney
General of the United States will be placed in the records of the Court
and we wish you well in your new office."
Attorney General Janet Reno said:
"Thank You, Mr. Chief Justice."

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 30, 1993
621
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York,
et al. On Exceptions to Report of Special Master. All pending motions
for leave to intervene and to file briefs as amici curiae are granted.
Two exceptions of Delaware sustained, one sustained in part. Excep-
tion of New York overruled. Case remanded to the Special Master for
further proceedings consistent with this opinion and for preparation of
an appropriate decree. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion
by Justice White with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
join.
No. 91–1160. A. J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Thomas E. Creech.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Stevens joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-742. Fargo Women's Health Organization, et al., Applicants
v. Edward T. Schafer, Governor of North Dakota, et al. The application
for stay and injunction pending appeal presented to Justice Blackmun
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The order heretofore en-
tered by Justice Blackmun on March 31, 1993, is vacated. Concurring
opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Souter joins. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1993
627
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
"
No. 92–1249. African American Voting Rights Legal Defense Fund,
Inc., et al., Appellants v. Roy Blunt, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Missouri. The judg-
ment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1800. Harlow Fay, Inc., Petitioner v. Federal Land Bank of
St. Louis. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Pioneer Investment Services Company v. Bruns-
wick Associates Limited Partnership, 507 U. S. (1993).
-
No. 91-1855. Alvin D. Pearson, et al., Petitioners v. James Edgar,
Governor of Illinois, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of City of Cincinnati v. Discovery
Network, Inc., 507 U. S. —- (1993).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-734. Reserve National Insurance Company, Applicant v. Ray
Crowell, et ux. The application for stay presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that exe-
cution upon the punitive damages portion of the judgment, entered
February 5, 1993, by the Supreme Court of Alabama, case Nos. 1911098,
1911099 and 1911157, is stayed pending the timely filing and disposition
by this Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari. If the petition for a
writ of certiorari is denied, this order is to terminate automatically.

628
MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1993
Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this order is to
remain in effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
No. D-1252. In the Matter of Disbarment of Melvin M. Lebetkin. It
is ordered that Melvin M. Lebetkin, of Kew Gardens, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1253. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Preston Perrin.
It is ordered that Richard Preston Perrin, of Washington, D. C., be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1254. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard J. Bodner. It is
ordered that Howard J. Bodner, of Rockville Centre, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1255. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry G. Rightmyer. It
is ordered that Larry G. Rightmyer, of St. Petersburg, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The motion of Massachusetts for divided argument and for addi-
tional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of intervenors
United Illuminating Company, et al. for divided argument is granted to
be divided as follows: 20 minutes for the plaintiffs and 10 minutes for
the intervenors. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of these motions.
No. 92-515. Wisconsin, Petitioner v. Todd Mitchell. The motion of re-
spondent for divided argument is denied.
No. 92-602. St. Mary's Honor Center, et al., Petitioners v. Melvin
Hicks. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 92-6033. William McNeil, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of the Acting Solicitor General to permit William K. Kelley, Es-
quire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.

MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1993
629
No. 92-7894. Carlos E. Restrepo, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until April 26, 1993, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
No. 92-7912. In Re Michael Anthony Miller, Petitioner. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule
39.8. Petitioner is allowed until April 26, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

OPINIONS
No. 91-1729. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Texas, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehn-
quist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-1521. United States, Petitioner v. Lowell Green. On writ of
certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The Court is
advised that respondent died March 24, 1993. The Court's order grant-
ing certiorari is vacated and the petition for certiorari is dismissed.
Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 13, 1993
649
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8305. James Dean Clark, Petitioner v. Arizona. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona is denied. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of
execution.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 14, 1993
651
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8307. James Dean Clark, Petitioner v. Samuel Lewis, Direc-
tor, Arizona Department of Corrections, and Roger Crist, Warden. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1993
653
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-418. A. J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Donald M. Paradis.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Arave v. Creech, 507 U. S. (1993).
No. 92-464. A. J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Albert Ray Beam.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration light of Arave v. Creech, 507 U. S.
(1993).
No. 92-1089. City of Seattle, et al., Petitioners v. Paul A. Bascomb,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority v. Met-
calf & Eddy, Inc., 506 U. S. (1993).
No.
--
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Jerry L. Hall, Petitioner v. Internal Revenue Service. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-
of-time, is denied.

No. Synnachia Carl McQueen, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.

654
MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1993
No. A-750. Carol A. Niznik, Applicant v. First Federal Savings and
Loan Association of Rochester. The application for stay of foreclosure
and foreclosure sale addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-1222. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nancy Ann Baker. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1231. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Gross. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1234. In the Matter of Disbarment of Wilfred Carlmond Rice.
Disbarment order entered
No. D-1235. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Masaharu Ushi-
jima. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1256. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter M. Lopez. It is
ordered that Peter M. Lopez, of Miami, Florida, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1257. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry Edward Gates,
Jr. It is ordered that Larry Edward Gates, Jr., of Myrtle Beach, South
Carolina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92–1214. Patricia Milligan-Jensen, Petitioner v. Michigan Tech-
nological University. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 92-7821. Lawrence K. Reichelt, Petitioner v. Daryl Gates, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until May 10, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dissent-
ing: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S.
928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Louisiana granted.

TUESDAY, APRIL 20, 1993
681
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. On Exceptions to Reports of the Special Master. Inter-
vention motions of certain amici curiae denied. All Exceptions filed to
Special Master's Reports are overruled. Summary judgment motions of
Nebraska and United States regarding the Inland Lakes' priority date
are granted as is Nebraska's partial summary judgment motion with re-
spect to issue of canal diversion limitations. All other summary judg-
ment motions are denied. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 91-1600. Hazen Paper Company, et al., Petitioners v. Walter F.
Biggins. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Chief Justice Rehn-
quist and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91–1135. Newark Morning Ledger Co. as Successor to the Her-
ald Company, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Souter with whom Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White and Jus-
tice Scalia join.

No. 91-1030. Pamela Withrow, Petitioner v. Robert Allen Williams,
Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion concurring in part and dissenting in
part by Justice O'Connor with whom Chief Justice Rehnquist joins.
Opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part by Justice Scalia with
whom Justice Thomas joins.
No. 91-7358. Todd A. Brecht, Petitioner v. Gordon A. Abrahamson,
Superintendent, Dodge Correctional Institution. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion
by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
Justice Blackmun joins and with whom Justice Souter joins in part. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting satement by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting statement by Justice Souter.

Easterwood; and
No. 91-1206. Lizzie Beatrice Easterwood, Petitioner v. CSX Trans-
portation, Inc. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
White. Opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Souter joins con-
curring in part and dissenting in part.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, APRIL 22, 1993
685
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDERS
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Appellate
Rules 3, 3.1, 4, 5.1, 6, 10, 12, 15, 25, 28, and 34, and to Forms 1, 2, and
3.
2. That the amendments to the Federal Rules of Appellate Proce-
dure shall take effect on December 1, 1993, and shall govern all pro-
ceedings in appellate cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings in appellate cases then pending.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Appellate Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sec-
tion 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1010, 1013, 1017, 2002, 2003, 2005, 3009, 3015, 3018, 3019, 3020,
5005, 6002, 6006, 6007, 9002, and new Rule 9036.
2. That the amendments to the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Proce-
dure shall take effect on August 1, 1993, and shall govern all proceed-
ings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
practicable, all proceedings in bankruptcy cases then pending.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of
Section 2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for the United States
District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
amendments to Civil Rules 1, 4, 5, 11, 12, 15, 16, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32,
33, 34, 36, 37, 38, 50, 52, 53, 54, 58, 71A, 72, 73, 74, 75, and 76, and new
Rule 4.1, and abrogation of Form 18-A, and amendments to Forms 2,

686
THURSDAY, APRIL 22, 1993
33, 34, and 34A, and new Forms 1A, 1B, and 35.
2. That the amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
shall take effect on December 1, 1993, and shall govern all proceedings
in civil cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable,
all proceedings in civil cases then pending.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
Statement by Justice White respecting these Rules.
Dissenting statement by Justice Scalia respecting these Rules in
which Justice Thomas joins and in which Justice Souter joins as to Part
II.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules 1, 3, 4, 5, 5.1, 6, 9, 12, 16, 17,
26.2, 32, 32.1, 40, 41, 44, 46, 49, 50, 54, 55, 57, and 58, and new Rule
26.3, and an amendment to Rule 8 of the Rules Governing Section 2255
Proceedings.
2. That the amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure
shall take effect on December 1, 1993, and shall govern all proceedings
in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practi-
cable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Sec-
tion 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Evidence for the United States District
Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein amend-
ments to Evidence Rules 101, 705, 1101.
2. That the amendments to the Federal Rules of Evidence shall take
effect on December 1, 1993, and shall govern in all proceedings there-
after commenced and insofar, as just and practicable, all proceedings
then pending.
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Evidence in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1993
687
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 91-1977. Robert E. Hatfield, Petitioner v. Burlington Northern
Railroad Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further
consideration in light of CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Easterwood, 507
U. S.
-
(1993).
No. 92-926. Harry K. Singletary, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Frank Elijah Smith. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment
is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Brecht v. Abrahamson, 507 U. S. (1993). Justice Blackmun, Jus-
tice Stevens and Justice O'Connor dissent.
-
No. 92-966. M. Maureen Polsby, Petitioner v. Donna E. Shalala, Sec-
retary of Health and Human Services, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of the position pres-
ently asserted by the Acting Solicitor General in his brief for the United
States filed March 5, 1993.
No. 92-1163. Harry K. Singletary, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Lloyd Duest. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is

688
MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1993
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Brecht v.
Abrahamson, 507 U. S. (1993). Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens
and Justice O'Connor dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. -. Harold K. Kalama, et ux., Petitioners v. Michelle Owen
Kelley, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ
of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-738. Dori De Falco, Petitioner v. Metro Dade County, et al.
The application for stay of elections addressed to the Chief Justice and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion of the Special Master for award of interim fees and re-
imbursement of expenses for the period June 22, 1992, through Febru-
ary 28, 1993, is granted and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$153,042.26 to be paid as follows: 40% by Kansas, 40% by Colorado and
20% by the United States.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. State of Wyoming.
The State of Nebraska's Motion for Leave to File Amended Petition for
an Apportionment of Non-Irrigation Season Flows and for the Asser-
tion of New Claims is denied without prejudice with respect to Count I.
The Special Master is directed to provide a recommendation to the
Court as to whether the motion for leave to file an amended petition
should be granted with respect to Counts II and III.
No. 92-1398. Ross Richardson, Chapter 7 Panel Trustee, Petitioner
v. Mt. Adams Furniture. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 92-1570. Farmers Insurance Group, dba Truck Insurance Ex-
change, dba Truck Underwriters Association, Petitioner v. Harold
Massey and Dorothy Massey. The application for stay of execution and
enforcement of judgment pending disposition of the petition for a writ
of certiorari addressed to Justice Kennedy and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 92-5653. Dorsie Lee Johnson, Jr., Petitioner v. Texas. The mo-
tion of Criminal Justice Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 92-7962. James R. Hunt, Jr., et ux., Petitioners v. Gerald W.
Robinson, Commissioner of Social Services of Massachusetts. The mo-
tion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Pe-

MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1993
689
titioners are allowed until May 17, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.

OPINIONS
No. 91-1594. Fred H. Edenfield, et al., Petitioners v. Scott Fane. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor.
No. 91-1306. United States, Petitioner v. Guy W. Olano, Jr., and
Raymond M. Gray. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-2003. United States, Petitioner v. California and California
State Board of Equalization. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 92-5653. Dorsie Lee Johnson, Jr., Petitioner v. Texas. Argued
by Mr. Michael E. Tigar for the petitioner and Mrs. Dana E. Parker for

Adjourned until Monday, May 3, 1993, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 3, 1993
705
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"I announce with great sorrow the death, on April 24, of Mrs. Earl
Warren, the widow of the late Chief Justice of the United States. The
Court expresses its deep sympathy to the Warren family."
OPINIONS
No. 91-1043. Professional Real Estate Investors, Inc., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by
Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice O'Con-
nor joins concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-8685. Terry Lynn Stinson, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy.
No. 92-1. Lynwood Moreau, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Johnny
Klevenhagen, Sheriff, Harris County, Texas, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 92-551. Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, et al., Petitioners v. Alpine Ridge Group, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White announced by
the Chief Justice.
No. 92–190. United States, Petitioner v. Idaho, ex rel. Director,
Idaho Department of Water Resources. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Idaho. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Idaho for further proceedings not inconsistent with

MONDAY, MAY 3, 1993

by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
No. 92-207. United States, Petitioner v. Xavier V. Padilla, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced
by the Chief Justice.

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8491. Larry Joe Johnson, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary,
Jr., Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Application for stay
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Florida is denied.

TUESDAY, MAY 4, 1993
713
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-834. Darryl Elroy Stewart, Applicant v. Texas. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, MAY 8, 1993
715
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8637. Larry Joe Johnson, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is denied.
Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of this appli-
cation and this petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8638. Larry Joe Johnson, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is denied.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application for
stay of execution. Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this application and this petition.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 17, 1993
721
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 92-949. El Vocero De Puerto Rico (Caribbean International
News Corp.), et al., Petitioners v. Puerto Rico, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico. Petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. The judgment is reversed and case is remanded
to the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-6173. Jackson Randall Bruce, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Stinson v. United States, 508 U. S. (1993).
No. 92-6612. Terry Lajuan Wright, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Stinson v. United States, 508 U. S. (1993).
-
No. 92-6907. Howard Small, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Stinson v. United States, 508 U. S. · — (1993).

No. D-1258. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerry B. Smith. It is or-
dered that Jerry B. Smith, of Coral Springs, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1259. In the Matter of Disbarment of Chester L. Brown. It is
ordered that Chester L. Brown, of Birmingham, Alabama, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 92-6732. William Thomas, Petitioner v. Ronald Reagan, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Justice White would grant the
petition, vacate the judgment and remand the case to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Leatherman v. Tarrant County Narcotics Intelli-
gence and Coordination Unit, 507 U. S. (1993).
