OPINIONS
No. 91-8199. Thomas Lee Deal, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor
join.
No. 92-259. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Sac and Fox
Nation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 92-114. Cardinal Chemical Company, etc., et al., Petitioners v.
Morton International Inc. On writ of certiorari to United States Court
of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Scalia in which Justice
Souter joins concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.

Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92–8706. John Christopher Sawyer, Petitioner v. James A. Col-
lins, Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Di-

MONDAY, MAY 17, 1993
769
vision. Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented
to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay of execution.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-8741. John Christopher Sawyer, Petitioner v. Texas. Applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1993
771
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-67. United States, Petitioner v. Orestes Luciano Abreu, and
United States, Petitioner v. James David Thornbrugh. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. The motion of respondent James Thornburgh for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgments are vacated and the cases are remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Deal v. United States, 508 U. S. ——— (1993).
-
No. 92-1442. Adaline B. Garcia, et vir, Petitioners v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United States, 506 U. S.
(1992).
No. 92-1452. Charlie Mae Bowens, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Republic National Bank of Miami v. United States, 506 U. S.
(1992).
No. 92–1458. Alberto A. Rosales, Sr., Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Ortega-Rodriguez v. United States, 507 U. S. . (1993).

772
No.
MONDAY, MAY 24, 1993

Richard J. Krantz, Petitioner v. Phillip Briggs, Superin-
tendent, Cook Inlet Pretrial Facility, Alaska Department of Correc-
tions. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari out-of-time is denied.

No. D-1244. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis Guthrie Gordon,
III. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1252. In the Matter of Disbarment of Melvin M. Lebetkin.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1267. In the Matter of Disbarment of William H. Manger. It is
ordered that William H. Manger, of Baltimore, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1268. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sam B. Dunford. It is
ordered that Sam B. Dunford, of Palm Springs, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $370.29 for the period Janu-
ary 1-March 31, 1993, to be paid equally by the parties.

ers v. Shannon Carter, a minor by and through her father, and next
friend, Emory D. Carter. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.

leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided

is denied.

motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
David C. Stebbins, Esquire, of Nashville, Tennessee, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent Donald Ray Middlebrooks in this
case.

OPINIONS
No. 91-1677. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Key-
stone Consolidated Industries, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion this Court.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Scalia joins all but Part III-B of
this opinion. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-1833. Michael E. Lincoln, Acting Director of the Indian
Health Service, et al., Petitioners v. Grover Vigil, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter announced by
the Chief Justice.
No. 92-166. Keene Corporation, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion filed by Justice Souter announced by
the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-2054. United States Department of Justice, et al., Petitioners
v. Vincent James Landano. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-

MONDAY, MAY 24, 1993
789
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1993
793
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-865. William T. Reil, Applicant v. Brenda K. Mitchell, Secre-
tary of Pennsylvania, et al. Application for stay addressed to Justice
Thomas and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 91-1600. Hazen Paper Company, et al., Petitioners v. Walter F.
Biggins. The motion of respondent to disallow costs is denied.
No. 92-519. Bolley Johnson, Speaker of the Florida House of Repre-
sentatives, et al., Appellants v. Miguel De Grandy, et al.;
No. 92–593. Miguel De Grandy, et al., Appellants v. Bolley Johnson,
Speaker of the Florida House of Representatives, et al.; and
No. 92-767. United States, Appellant v. Florida, et al. The motion of
the Acting Solicitor General for divided argument is granted in part. A
total of 30 minutes for oral argument is allotted to the Acting Solicitor
General and a total of 15 minutes for oral argument is allotted to the De
Grandy plaintiffs. The motion of Florida and the state officials for di-
vided argument are denied. A total of 45 minutes for oral argument is
allotted to Florida and the state officials.
No. 92-6281. Robert Hagen, Petitioner v. Utah. The motion of Ute
Indian Tribe for leave to intervene is denied. Justice Blackmun would
grant this motion.
No. 92-8362. Richard John Kadunc, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 22, 1993,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
No. 92-8425. Sylvester Jones, Petitioner v. William K. Suter, Clerk,
Supreme Court of the United States, et al. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner
is allowed until June 22, 1993, within which to pay the docketing fee

794
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1993
required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari.

No. 92-8686. In Re Leonel Torres Herrera, Petitioner. Petitions for

of mandamus and/or prohibition denied.

TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1993
803
No. 92-1837. In Re James Blodgett, Superintendent, Washington
State Penitentiary, Petitioner. The motion of petitioner to expedite
consideration of the petition for a writ of mandamus and/or prohibition
is granted. The motion of respondent Charles Campbell for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of mandamus
and/or prohibition denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 92-5789. Rachel C. Martin, Petitioner v. Margaret Kynard, et
al.;
No. 92-7401. Alvin D. Esnault, Petitioner v. Colorado, et al.;
No. 92-7774. Curtis Lee Echols, Jr., Petitioner v. A. G. Thomas,
Warden;
No. 92-7780. David William Peabody, Petitioner v. City of Phoenix,
et al.; and
No. 92-7813. Thomas Wayne Nguyen, Petitioner v. United States.
Petitions for rehearing are denied.

The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, June 1, 1993, until Mon-
day, June 7, 1993.

OPINIONS
No. 92-603. Federal Communications Commission and United
States, Petitioners v. Beach Communications, Inc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further
consideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 92-641. Leonard Nobelman, et ux., Petitioners v. American Sav-
ings Bank, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.

808
TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1993
No. 92-34. Musick, Peeler & Garrett, et al., Petitioners v. Employ-
ers Insurance of Wausau, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas
with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 91-1671. William J. Mertens, Alex W. Bandrowski, James A.
Clark, and Russell Franz, Petitioners v. Hewitt Associates. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White, with whom Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens and
Justice O'Connor join.
No. 92-5129. John Sullivan, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further consideration.
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Concurring opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist.
No. 91-8674. John Angus Smith, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring
opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom Justice Stevens and Justice Souter join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1993
815
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92–1296. United States, Petitioner v. William H. Melcher, Act-
ing Director of Revenue of Missouri, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v.
Texas, 507 U. S. (1993).
- —
No. 92-1297. William H. Melcher, Acting Director of Revenue of
Missouri, et al. Petitioners v. United States. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v.
California, 507 U. S. (1993).
—
No. 92-1566. MCI Telecommunications Corporation, Petitioner v.
Credit Builders of America, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to
consider the question of mootness.
No. 92-1630. Lomas Mortgage USA, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel
Wiese, et al.; Goldome Realty Credit Corp., Petitioner v. Mark Chris-
tian Saugstad, et al.; and General Motors Acceptance Corporation v.
Noel G. Cervantes, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgments are vacated and the cases are re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for
further consideration in light of Nobelman v. American Savings Bank,
508 U. S. (1993).

816
MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1993
No. 92-6554. Saul Johnson, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Cir-
cuit, for further consideration in light of Sullivan v. Louisiana, 508
U. S. (1993).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1256. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter M. Lopez. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. 92-1871. Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company, Peti-
tioner v. Corman Construction, Inc., et al. The motion of Common-
wealth Land Title Insurance Company to intervene in order to file a
petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 92-1183. Stephen A. Knox, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit granted.
No. 92-97. Northwest Airlines, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. County of
Kent, Michigan, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 92-854. Central Bank of Denver, N.A., Petitioner v. First Inter-
state Bank of Denver, N.A. and Jack K. Naber. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
granted limited to Question 2 presented by the petition. In addition to
Question 2, the parties are directed first to brief and argue the follow-
ing question: "Whether there is an implied private right of action for
aiding and abetting violations of Section 10(b) of the Securities Ex-
change Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5."
No. 92-7794. John Pasch, Petitioner v. Illinois. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Illinois granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED

No. 92-8645. In Re Michael Paige, Petitioner; and
827
No. 92-8679. In Re Rory O'Donnell, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
habeas corpus are denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 92-8357. In Re Roger Dean Mosby, Petitioner; and
No. 92-8408. In Re Roy A. Day, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
mandamus denied.
No. 92-8333. In Re Louis R. Leuellyn, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED

Superintendent, Dodge Correctional Institution;

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 7, 1993, until Friday,
June 11, 1993.

No. 92-621. Donald Neal Rake, et al., Petitioners v. William J.
Wade, Trustee. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Thomas.
No. 92-484. United States National Bank of Oregon, Petitioner v. In-
dependent Insurance Agents of America Inc., et al.; and
No. 92–507. Eugene R. Ludwig, Comptroller of the Currency, et al.,
Petitioners v. Independent Insurance Agents of America, Inc., et al.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Souter.
No. 91-7604. Jeffrey Antoine, Petitioner v. Byers & Anderson, Inc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-2019. Minnesota, Petitioner v. Timothy Dickerson. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion
by Chief Justice Rehnquist, with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice
Thomas join, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 91–2024. Lamb's Chapel and John Steigerwald, Petitioners v.
Center Moriches Union Free School District, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice Scalia with whom Justice Thomas joins concurring in the
judgment.

MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1993
833
No. 91-2079. Good Samaritan Hospital, et al., Petitioners v. Donna
E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services. On writ of certio-
rari to the United State Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Souter with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Scalia join.
No. 91-1738. Jerry D. Gilmore, Petitioner v. Kevin Taylor. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist.
Justice Souter joins all but footnote 3 of this opinion. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor, with whom Justice White joins, concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Stevens
joins.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 1993
839
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-948. Church of the Lukumi Babalu Aye, Inc., and Ernesto
Pichardo, Petitioners v. City of Hialeah. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Justice Kennedy delivered the opinion of the
Court except as to Part II-A-2. Opinion by Justice Scalia with whom
Chief Justice Rehnquist joins concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in part and concurring
in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun, with whom Justice
O'Connor joins, concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-1513. United States Department of the Treasury and Mitchell
A. Levine, Assistant Commissioner, Petitioners v. George Fabe, Su-
perintendent of Insurance of Ohio. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part and reversed in part and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice Scalia, Jus-
tice Souter and Justice Thomas join.
No. 92-515. Wisconsin, Petitioner v. Todd Mitchell. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Chief Justice
Rehnquist.
Adjourned until Monday, June 14, 1993, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1993
841
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 92-155. Statewide Reapportionment Advisory Committee, et
al., Appellants v. Nick Theodore, et al.; and
No. 92–219. Carroll A. Campbell, Jr., Governor of South Carolina,
Appellant v. Nick Theodore, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of South Carolina. The judgment is vacated
and the cases are remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of South Carolina for further consideration in light of the posi-
tion presented by the Acting Solicitor General in his brief for the
United States filed May 7, 1993.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 92-253. Illinois Department of Corrections, Petitioner v. Marvin
Flowers. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Gilmore v. Taylor, 508 U. S. — (1993).
No. 92-568. Ohio, Petitioner v. David Wyant, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. The motion of respond-
ent Robert E. Blazer for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The motion of respondent David Wyant for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Mark Staton for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Aaron
L. Plessinger for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
motion of respondent Clancy Van Gundy for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Bryan Krebs for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent
Charles Culp for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The

842
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1993
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further consider-
ation in light of Wisconsin v. Mitchell, 508 U. S. ——— (1993).
No. 92-720. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner, v. Mt. Diablo Hospital Medical Center. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Good Samari-
tan Hospital v. Shalala, 508 U. S. (1993).
-
No. 92-1547. Interstate Commerce Commission, Petitioner v. Trans-
con Lines, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Reiter v. Cooper, 507 U. S. — (1993).
No. 92-6931. Terrance Sullivan, Petitioner v. Carl Sokolski. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of An-
toine v. Byers & Anderson, Inc., 508 U. S. (1993).
-

MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1993
843
No. D-1272. In the Matter of Disbarment of Geoffrey T. Williams,
Sr. It is ordered that Geoffrey T. Williams, Sr., of Fairfax, Virginia,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1273. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Joseph Golds-
borough, Jr. It is ordered that George Joseph Goldsborough, Jr., of
Easton, Maryland, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to
show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. D-1274. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joel P. Kraemer. It is
ordered that Joel P. Kraemer, of Madison, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1275. In the Matter of Disbarment of Matthew E. Segal. It is
ordered that Matthew E. Segal, of Cherry Hill, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1276. In the Matter of Disbarment of William P. Teevens. It
is ordered that William P. Teevens, of Rapid City, South Dakota, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92-7549. Thomas Schiro, Petitioner v. Richard Clark, Superin-
tendent, Indiana State Prison, et al. The motion for appointment of
counsel is granted and it is ordered that Monica Foster, Esq., of Indian-
apolis, Indiana, is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this
case.

OPINIONS
No. 91-1721. Northeastern Florida Chapter of the Associated Gen-
eral Contractors of America, Petitioner v. City of Jacksonville, Florida,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice
Blackmun joins.
No. 91-2051. South Dakota, Petitioner v. Gregg Bourland, etc., et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Souter joins.
No. 91-904. Concrete Pipe and Products of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Construction Laborers Pension Trust for Southern California.

860
MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1993
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter. Justice
Scalia does not join Part III-B-1-b of this opinion. Concurring opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-610. Local 144 Nursing Home Pension Fund, et al., Petition-
ers v. Nicholas Demisay, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of the
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with
whom Justice White and Justice Blackmun join, concurring in the
judgment.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 18, 1993
863
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-794. Henry Harper, et al., Petitioners v. Virginia Depart-
ment of Taxation. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Vir-
ginia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Virginia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice
Scalia. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice White joins con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O'Connor with whom Chief Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 91-1826. Janet Reno, Attorney General, et al., Petitioners v.
Catholic Social Services, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice White and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 91-1958. Donald L. Helling, et al., Petitioners v. William McKin-
ney. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice
Scalia joins.
No. 92-94. Larry Zobrest, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Catalina Foot-
hills School District. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Chief Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with
whom Justice Souter joins and with whom Justice Stevens and Justice
O'Connor join as to Part I. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor,
with whom Justice Stevens joins.
Adjourned until Monday, June 21, 1993, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1993
865
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
The Chief Justice said:
"The Court at this time wishes to note for the record that William C.
Bryson has been serving as Acting Solicitor General since January past.
The Court recognizes the considerable responsibility that has been
placed upon you, Mr. Bryson, to represent the government of the
United States before this Court. On behalf of my colleagues, I thank
you for a job well done and you have our sincere appreciation.
"The Court now recognizes the Attorney General, General Reno."
Attorney General Reno said:
"Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court, I have the honor to
present to the Court the Solicitor General of the United States, The
Honorable Drew S. Days, III, of Connecticut.”
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Solicitor General, the Court welcomes you to the performance of
the important office that you have assumed, to represent the govern-
ment of the United States before this Court. You follow in the footsteps.
of other outstanding attorneys who have held your new office. Your
commission will be duly recorded by the Clerk."
Solicitor General Days said:
"Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1347. Salvatore R. Curiale, Superintendent of Insurance of
the State of New York, etc., Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Ap-
pellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Depart-
ment, for further consideration in light of United States Department of
the Treasury v. Fabe, 508 U. S. (1993).
-

866
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1993
No. 92-1436. Teamsters Pension Trust Fund of Philadelphia and Vi-
cinity, et al., Petitioners v. Fuqua Industries, Inc. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of Concrete Pipe
and Products of California, Inc. v. Construction Laborers Pension
Trust for Southern California, 508 U. S. (1993).
—
No. 92-7897. John Billy-Eko, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position asserted by the Acting Solicitor General in his brief for the
United States filed May 28, 1993.
No. 92-8231. Mark Williams, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Crosby v. United States, 506 U. S. (1993).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 92-1074. John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Peti-
tioner v. Harris Trust and Savings Bank, as Trustee of the Sperry Mas-
ter Retirement Trust No. 2. The motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.
No. 92-1223. United States Department of Defense, et al., Petition-
ers v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. The motion of National
Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation, Inc. for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 92–1441. Harold E. Staples, III, Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 92–1637. Irene M. Ibarra, Executive Director, Colorado Depart-
ment of Social Services, et al., Petitioners v. Duc Van Le, etc. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.

MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1993
867
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 92-8425. Sylvester Jones, Petitioner v. William K. Suter, Clerk,
Supreme Court of the United States, et al. The motion of petitioner for
reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied.
No. 92-8484. In Re Roy A. Day, Petitioner. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Peti-
tioner is allowed until July 12, 1993, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens would deny the peti-
tion for a writ of mandamus.
No. 92-8532. Michael Antonelli, Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule
39.8. Petitioner is allowed until July 12, 1993, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.

No. 92-8462. Greg Ward, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary, Secre-

No. 92–1668. S. R. Witkowski, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Lewis

Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.

of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas
denied.

American Telephone & Telegraph Company. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

The motion of National Ocean Industries Association, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit, denied.
No. 92-7985. Robin H. Guy, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin denied. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Thomas joins.
No. 92-8725. Richard Paul Zuckerman, Petitioner v. United States.
The application for stay addressed to The Chief Justice and referred to
the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.

OPINIONS
No. 92-466. Brooke Group Ltd., Petitioner v. Brown & Williamson
Tobacco Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens in which Justice
White and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 92–344. Chris Sale, Acting Commissioner, Immigration and Nat-
uralization Service, et al., Petitioners v. Haitian Centers Council, Inc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 91-2045. R. Gordon Darby, et al., Petitioners v. Henry G. Cisne-
ros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity

884
MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1993
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Chief Jus-
tice Rehnquist, Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join all but Part III of
this opinion.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1993
889
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court

the Court except as to Part III-D. Justice O'Connor joins Parts I, II,
III-A, III-b, and IV of this opinion. Justice Scalia joins all but Part III-
C of this opinion. Justice Kennedy joins Parts I, II, III-C and IV of this
opinion. Justice Souter joins all but Parts III-A, III-B and III-D of this
opinion. Justice Souter with whom Justice Kennedy joins, concurring in

mun joins.
Adjourned until Monday, June 28, 1993, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1993
893
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"As most of you know, our esteeemed colleague, Justice White, is re-
tiring from this bench and his colleagues have sent him this letter on
this occasion which I will now read."
"Dear Byron:
"Your decision to retire from the Court has brought to each of us a
profound sense of sadness. You came here more than thirty-one years
ago, and have played a pivotal part in the deliberations and decisions of
this institution with three different Chief Justices during the adminis-
tration of eight different Presidents.
-
"You brought to the Court a reputation for excellence in many
fields scholar-athlete, combat intelligence officer in the South Pacific
during World War II, successful private lawyer, Deputy Attorney Gen-
eral. Your long service here has greatly enhanced that reputation, as
you have exhibited a firm resolve not to be classified in any one doc-
trinal pigeonhole. The important opinions which you have authored for
the Court in virtually every field of law with which we deal will remain
as a testament to your years of service here.
"Every cloud, they say, has a silver lining; for us the silver lining to
your retirement is that you leave in good health, and plan to remain
here in the Washington area, at least for the time being. You will be
missed at our Conferences, but we will continue to enjoy your friend-
ship which means so much to each of us.
Antonin Scalia
Anthony M. Kennedy
David H. Souter
Clarence Thomas
Affectionately,
Justice White replied as follows:
"Dear Colleagues,
William H. Rehnquist
Harry A. Blackmun
John Paul Stevens
Sandra Day O'Connor"
"I am grateful for your very generous letter on the occasion of my
retirement, which is now upon me. There is no doubt that I shall miss
the Court very much, primarily because I shall no longer have the

894
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1993
pleasure and excitement of working in a small group of nine Justices, all
of whom day after day and year after year are together dealing with the
same issues and cases in an attempt to arrive at satisfactory decisions. I
have sat with 20 Justices in my time here and have had great respect
for the ability and integrity of each of them. I have treasured their
friendship. Of course, Justices differ with one another on all sorts of is-
sues, but we have not held grudges and have gotten along remarkably
well. That is how it should be.
"This Court is a very small organization for the freight it carries, and
its work is made possible only by the competent and dedicated service
of those who work here. I shall always be grateful to all of them for
their willing, friendly and reliable help down through the years.
"Since I remain a federal judge and will likely sit on Courts of Ap-
peals from time to time, it will be necessary for me to follow the Court's
work. No longer will I be able to agree with or dissent from a Court's
opinion. Hence, like any other Court of Appeals judge, I hope the
Court's mandates will be clear, crisp, and leave those of us below with
as little room as possible for disagreement about their meaning.
"The Court is a great institution, and I wish it well. It has been good
to me.
Cheers,
Byron"
OPINIONS
No. 91-1111. Hartford Fire Insurance Co., et al., Petitioners v. Cali-
fornia, et al.; and
No. 91–1128. Merrett Underwriting Agency Management Limited,
et al., Petitioners v. California, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed in part and reversed in part and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice Souter
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to Parts I, II(A), III, and IV, and an opinion with
respect to Part II(B) in which Justice White, Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens join. Justice Scalia delivered the opinion of the Court
with respect to Part I, and delivered a dissenting opinion with respect
to Part II, in which Justice O'Connor, Justice Kennedy, and Justice
Thomas join.

MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1993
ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is ordered
that Justice Thomas be, and he is hereby, assigned to the Tenth Circuit
as Circuit Justice pending further order of the Court.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday in Oc-
tober, 1993, at which time the October 1992 Term will adjourn.

"I am authorized to announce that all cases submitted to the Court
for decision have been acted upon by the Court. Accordingly, it is or-
dered that those cases remaining on the docket, but not ready for con-
sideration, are continued to the session of the Court beginning October
4, 1993. The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday
in October, 1993, at which time the October 1992 Term will adjourn.
"On behalf of each Justice, I thank all members of the Supreme Court
staff for their continued dedication to the work of the Court during the
Term. The increased use of automation has made our workload much
more manageable. The commitment and professionalism of the Court
staff are recognized by the bar and the public. Such dedicated service
makes the heavy workload of the Court much easier for each member of
the Court."
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and
Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-9100. Curtis Paul Harris, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.

920
MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1993
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay of execution.

den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia is
denied.

den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

No. D-1277. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert P. Goldberg. It
is ordered that Robert P. Goldberg, of Honolulu, Hawaii, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1278. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Joseph Rapp. It is
ordered that John Joseph Rapp, of Honolulu, Hawaii, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1279. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Lloyd Pipkins.
It is ordered that Richard Lloyd Pipkins, of Las Vegas, Nevada, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1280. In the Matter of Disbarment of George F. Wood. It is
ordered that George F. Wood, of Sanford, Maine, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

dered that F. James Bear, of National City, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

929
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-71 (O.T. 1993). Board of Education of the Kiryas Joel Village
School District, Applicant v. Louis Grumet, et al.; and
No. A-72 (O.T. 1993). Board of Education of the Monroe-Woodbury
Central School District, Applicant v. Louis Grumet, et al. The applica-
tions for stay of the judgment of the Court of Appeals of New York,
case No. 120, presented to Justice Thomas and by him referred to the
Court are granted pending the timely filing and disposition by this
Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 93-5657. Carl Eugene Kelly, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Ginsburg took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this application and this petition.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, AUGUST 24, 1993
945
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
CERTIORARI DISMISSED
No. 93-5702. Michael Durocher, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The motion to proceed
in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed by peti-
tioner is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Florida is dismissed. The application for stay of execution of
sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to
the Court is denied. Justice Ginsburg took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion, petition and application.
CERTIORARI DISMISSED
No. 93-5715. Michael J. Minerva, Capital Collateral Representative,
et al., as next friends to Michael Durocher, Petitioners v. Harry K.
Singletary, Jr., Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by Michael Durocher is granted. The petition for a writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit is dismissed. The application for stay of execution of sentence of
death presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Justice Ginsburg took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion, petition and application.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
965
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Pow-
ell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the period from September 27,
1993, through June 10, 1994, and for such time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294 (a), is or-
dered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec.
295.

No. 93-44. Turner Broadcasting System, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Federal Communications Commission, et al. Appeal from United States
District Court for the District of Columbia. In this case probable juris-
diction is noted. The brief of appellants is to be filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, November
9, 1993. The briefs of appellees are to be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, December 7, 1993.
A reply brief, if any, is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon op-
posing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, December 21, 1993. Rule
29 does not apply.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1993
971
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
Marshal Wong said:
"All Rise, the President of the United States."
The Chief Justice said:
"On behalf of the Court, Mr. President, I extend to you a warm wel-
come. This special sitting of the Court is held today to receive the com-
mission of the newly appointed Associate Justice of the Supreme Court
of the United States, Ruth Bader Ginsburg. The Court now recognizes
the Attorney General of the United States, Ms. Janet Reno."
The Attorney General said:
"Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court, I have the commis-
sion which has been issued to the Honorable Ruth Bader Ginsburg as an
Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. The com-
mission has been duly signed by the President of the United States and
attested by me as the Attorney General of the United States. I move
that the Clerk read the commission and that it be made part of the per-
manent records of this Court.”
The Chief Justice said:
"Thank you, Ms. Reno, your motion is granted. Mr. Clerk, will you
please read the commission?"
The Clerk read the commission:
"William Jefferson Clinton, President of the United States of
America,
"To All Who Shall See These Presents, Greeting:
"Know Ye; That reposing special trust and confidence in the wisdom,
uprightness, and learning of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, of New York, I
have nominated, and, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate,
do appoint her an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United
States and do authorize and empower her to execute and fulfill the du-
ties of that office according to the Constitution and Laws of the said
United States, and to Have and to Hold the said Office, with all the
powers, privileges and emoluments to the same of right appertaining,
unto Her, the said Ruth Bader Ginsburg, during her good behavior.
"In Testimony whereof, I have caused these Letters to be made pat-
ent and the seal of the Department of Justice to be hereunto affixed.

972
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1993
"Done at the City of Washington, this fifth day of August, in the year
of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and ninety-three, and of the In-
dependence of the United States of America the two hundred and
eighteenth.
"By the President: William Jefferson Clinton.
"Janet Reno, Attorney General."
The Chief Justice said:
"I now ask the Chief Deputy Clerk of the Court to escort Justice
Ginsburg to the bench."
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Ginsburg, are you ready to take the oath?"
Justice Ginsburg said:
"I am."
The Chief Justice said:
"Please repeat after me."
Justice Ginsburg said:
"I, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, do solemnly swear that I will administer
justice without respect to persons and do equal right to the poor and to
the rich and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform
all the duties incumbent upon me as Associate Justice of the Supreme
Court of the United States under the Constitution and Laws of the
United States, so help me God."
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Ginsburg, on behalf of all the members of the Court, it is a
pleasure to extend to you a very warm welcome as an Associate Justice
of the Court and to wish for you a long and happy career in our common
calling."
The Chief Justice said:
"Effective with the appointment of Justice Ginsburg, an order has
been entered by the Court today allotting the circuit justices as
follows."
ORDER
It is ordered that the following allotment be made of the Chief Justice
and Associate Justices of this Court among the circuits, pursuant to
Title 28, United States Code, Section 42 and that such allotment be en-
tered of record, effective October 1, 1993, viz:
For the District of Columbia Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief
Justice,

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1993
973
For the First Circuit, David H. Souter, Associate Justice,
For the Second Circuit, Clarence Thomas, Associate Justice,
For the Third Circuit, David H. Souter, Associate Justice,
For the Fourth Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice,
For the Fifth Circuit, Antonin Scalia, Associate Justice,
For the Sixth Circuit, John Paul Stevens, Associate Justice,
For the Seventh Circuit, John Paul Stevens, Associate Justice,
For the Eighth Circuit, Harry A. Blackmun, Associate Justice,
For the Ninth Circuit, Sandra Day O'Connor, Associate Justice,
For the Tenth Circuit, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Associate Justice,
For the Eleventh Circuit, Anthony M. Kennedy, Associate Justice,
For the Federal Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice.
Adjourned until Monday, October 4, 1993, at 10 o'clock.
